content: Read food labels. Before you buy anything at the grocery store, quickly look over the label and see if HFCS is listed in the ingredients. If you see HFCS, pick out an alternative brand of the same food without it. This may take you a while on your first few shopping trips, but soon you’ll figure out which brands to buy and which ones to avoid. [2] Some brands may advertise “no high fructose corn syrup” on the package, only to have it listed in the ingredients under a different name. HFCS is also called: corn sugar, maize syrup, glucose syrup, fructose syrup, isolated fructose, and crystalline fructose. [3] Be selective when buying “natural” or “organic. ” The word “natural” can be placed on a wide variety of foods containing HFCS, as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn’t regulate the label. Even a food labeled “100% organic” may contain organic HFCS, so it is important to always examine the ingredient and nutrition facts labels. You’ll usually spend a bit more to get HFCS-free organic foods, but the peace of mind is well worth it. [4] To find organic produce in your local grocery store you may need to go toward aisles set aside in a health food area. Many breads tout their “whole grain” status as a way to hide their inclusion of HFCS and harmful chemicals. Whole grain items are usually the best choice, but they are not all equal in quality. [5] Do a pantry purge. Go into your kitchen, open up your pantry, and look at the nutrition label for each food item that you own. Have a trashcan nearby and toss any foods with HFCS into it. Keep going until your pantry is “clean.” Then, head out to the store to buy non-HFCS foods to replace your stock. If you aren’t comfortable throwing away the food outright, you can always donate it to a food bank. However, that could also be considered just passing the nutrition problem along. It’s your call. Go for fresh foods, instead of canned or frozen. Canned fruit is convenient, but it is stripped of its fiber during processing. A piece of whole fruit can give you a fiber boost along with the sweetness of natural sugar. Exchange canned items, such as premade pasta sauce, for healthier options, like making your own sauce out of fresh tomatoes. [6] Go with plain foods. Choose basic vanilla yogurt, steel-cut oatmeal, and other foods without sauces or toppings. HFCS often hides in fruit toppings in otherwise healthy food options, like yogurt. By adding your own fresh fruit, such as strawberry slices, you can control the portion sizes as well. [7] For example, some sweetened yogurts contain over 40 grams (1.4 ounces) of sugar, including HFCS. [8] Don’t forget spices when adding flavor to plain foods. Cinnamon, ginger, and even pepper are all good options. Buy higher quality sweets. If you have a bit of a sweet tooth, that is okay. Just buy candies and treats made under the highest production standards, even if they are imported. They may be more expensive, but counteract this by allowing yourself only one small piece as an occasional treat. [9] Use fruit as a sweetener. Choose your favorite fruits, such as bananas, and incorporate them into foods that normally would contain extra sugars or HFCS. Mix banana slices into your steel-cut oatmeal or into plain, vanilla yogurt. Dates or bananas can also substitute for sugar in many baked recipes. [10] Regular table sugar is another option. However, still try to use any sweeteners, even natural ones, in moderation. Choose honey as a sweetener. Buy some raw honey at your local farmer’s market or specialty grocery. Add it into foods 1 teaspoon (5 ml) at a time to sweeten them up. Not only will you get the flavor, you’ll get antioxidants and essential nutrients, like vitamin B6. [11] Pack healthy snacks. To keep yourself from reaching for that HFCS-filled candy bar, pack some fruit slices in your bag for the day. Or, get a small container of hummus and some pre-cut carrot sticks. Not only will you avoid the negative effects of HFCS, you’ll get a boost of vitamins and nutrients. [12] Make your own salad dressing or other condiments. Many salad dressings advertise themselves as “low-calorie” or “low fat” and then compensate for the missing flavor by adding in HFCS. Create your own dressing by mixing together some olive oil, pepper, lemon juice, and balsamic vinegar. Experiment with recipes for other condiments too, like ketchup , barbeque sauce , mayo , or mustard . [13] Watch your portion sizes with condiments as well. A single tablespoon of barbecue sauce can cost you upwards of 5 grams (0.18 oz) of sugar or HFCS. Avoid canned or bottled beverages. Sports drinks, sodas, and flavored teas or lemonades are usually packed to the brim with HFCS. Be wary when choosing diet or “zero” drinks as well, since they often contain artificial sweeteners. If you must get your soda fix, buy drinks from bottlers who’ve chosen to use only natural cane sugar. [14] Check the Passover section of your supermarket. Some soda companies produce a sugar/sucrose-based version of their products around Passover for Jews who are restricted by custom from eating corn during this time. Avoid fast food. HFCS is hidden throughout many different types of fast food to increase flavor. Aside from the obvious areas, like sweets, you’ll also find HFCS in burgers, chicken patties, and other surprising foods. Eat foods made from natural ingredients at home to control what goes into the final product. [15] Avoid boxed or prepackaged meals. It’s good that you are trying to eat at home, but don’t make the mistake of taking the easy route with boxed meals. If HFCS is not in the main part of the meal, such as the pasta in boxed macaroni and cheese, then it is likely in the sauce packet. If you are looking for a meal shortcut without HFCS, buy precooked main dishes, like roasted chicken, from your local deli. [16] Choose 100% juice over juice cocktails. With pure juice drinks you’ll get natural sugars, whereas cocktails are often packed with HFCS and other artificial ingredients. It’s still a good idea to limit the amount of juice that you drink overall. As an alternative, pick up a piece of whole fruit and get the fiber benefits. [17] Use caution when buying breakfast cereals and granola bars. Some granola bars actually have more sugar than their chocolate counterparts. Try replacing a sugar-filled cereal with steel-cut oatmeal instead. [18]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup">How to Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Claudia Carberry, RD</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Making_Healthy_Food_Choices_sub" id="">Making Healthy Food Choices</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Making_Substitutions_sub" id="">Making Substitutions</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Staying_Away_from_Problem_Foods_sub" id="">Staying Away from Problem Foods</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd">Claudia Carberry, RD</a>. Claudia Carberry is an Outpatient Dietitian at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. She received her MS in Nutrition from the University of Tennessee Knoxville in 2010.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">20 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>High fructose corn syrup (HFCS) is used as a sweetener for many processed foods. To eliminate HFCS from your diet, start by closely reading nutrition labels before buying foods. Avoid canned, frozen, or prepackaged meals. Go with whole foods, like fresh bananas or apples, instead. When baking or cooking, get creative and use healthy sugar substitutes, like honey or mashed fruit.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup></p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Healthy_Food_Choices_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Healthy_Food_Choices">Making Healthy Food Choices</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_7df7e359c9" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7df7e359c9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Read food labels.</b> Before you buy anything at the grocery store, quickly look over the label and see if HFCS is listed in the ingredients. If you see HFCS, pick out an alternative brand of the same food without it. This may take you a while on your first few shopping trips, but soon you’ll figure out which brands to buy and which ones to avoid.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Some brands may advertise “no high fructose corn syrup” on the package, only to have it listed in the ingredients under a different name. HFCS is also called: corn sugar, maize syrup, glucose syrup, fructose syrup, isolated fructose, and crystalline fructose.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_b351fac3c0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b351fac3c0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be selective when buying “natural” or “organic.</b>” The word “natural” can be placed on a wide variety of foods containing HFCS, as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn’t regulate the label. Even a food labeled “100% organic” may contain organic HFCS, so it is important to always examine the ingredient and nutrition facts labels. You’ll usually spend a bit more to get HFCS-free organic foods, but the peace of mind is well worth it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>To find organic produce in your local grocery store you may need to go toward aisles set aside in a health food area.</li>
<li>Many breads tout their “whole grain” status as a way to hide their inclusion of HFCS and harmful chemicals. Whole grain items are usually the best choice, but they are not all equal in quality.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_136d1af2d3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_136d1af2d3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do a pantry purge.</b> Go into your kitchen, open up your pantry, and look at the nutrition label for each food item that you own. Have a trashcan nearby and toss any foods with HFCS into it. Keep going until your pantry is “clean.” Then, head out to the store to buy non-HFCS foods to replace your stock.

<ul>
<li>If you aren’t comfortable throwing away the food outright, you can always donate it to a food bank. However, that could also be considered just passing the nutrition problem along. It’s your call.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_76cdd06806" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_76cdd06806')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Go for fresh foods, instead of canned or frozen.</b> Canned fruit is convenient, but it is stripped of its fiber during processing. A piece of whole fruit can give you a fiber boost along with the sweetness of natural sugar. Exchange canned items, such as premade pasta sauce, for healthier options, like making your own sauce out of fresh tomatoes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5478a9aa7a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5478a9aa7a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Go with plain foods.</b> Choose basic vanilla yogurt, steel-cut oatmeal, and other foods without sauces or toppings. HFCS often hides in fruit toppings in otherwise healthy food options, like yogurt. By adding your own fresh fruit, such as strawberry slices, you can control the portion sizes as well.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, some sweetened yogurts contain over 40 grams (1.4 ounces) of sugar, including HFCS.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Don’t forget spices when adding flavor to plain foods. Cinnamon, ginger, and even pepper are all good options.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_2f5f1f8af7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2f5f1f8af7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Buy higher quality sweets.</b> If you have a bit of a sweet tooth, that is okay. Just buy candies and treats made under the highest production standards, even if they are imported. They may be more expensive, but counteract this by allowing yourself only one small piece as an occasional treat.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Substitutions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Substitutions">Making Substitutions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5745c37ece" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5745c37ece')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use fruit as a sweetener.</b> Choose your favorite fruits, such as bananas, and incorporate them into foods that normally would contain extra sugars or HFCS. Mix banana slices into your steel-cut oatmeal or into plain, vanilla yogurt. Dates or bananas can also substitute for sugar in many baked recipes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Regular table sugar is another option. However, still try to use any sweeteners, even natural ones, in moderation.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_7ca43839e7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7ca43839e7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose honey as a sweetener.</b> Buy some raw honey at your local farmer’s market or specialty grocery. Add it into foods 1 teaspoon (5 ml) at a time to sweeten them up. Not only will you get the flavor, you’ll get antioxidants and essential nutrients, like vitamin B6.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_0ac3cc23b1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0ac3cc23b1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pack healthy snacks.</b> To keep yourself from reaching for that HFCS-filled candy bar, pack some fruit slices in your bag for the day. Or, get a small container of hummus and some pre-cut carrot sticks. Not only will you avoid the negative effects of HFCS, you’ll get a boost of vitamins and nutrients.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_aea1275925" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_aea1275925')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make your own salad dressing or other condiments.</b> Many salad dressings advertise themselves as “low-calorie” or “low fat” and then compensate for the missing flavor by adding in HFCS. Create your own dressing by mixing together some olive oil, pepper, lemon juice, and balsamic vinegar. Experiment with recipes for other condiments too, like <a href="/Make-Tomato-Ketchup" title="Make Tomato Ketchup">ketchup</a>, <a href="/Make-Barbecue-Sauce" title="Make Barbecue Sauce">barbeque sauce</a>, <a href="/Make-Mayonnaise" title="Make Mayonnaise">mayo</a>, or <a href="/Make-Mustard-from-Scratch" title="Make Mustard from Scratch">mustard</a>.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Watch your portion sizes with condiments as well. A single tablespoon of barbecue sauce can cost you upwards of 5 grams (0.18 oz) of sugar or HFCS.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Staying_Away_from_Problem_Foods_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Staying_Away_from_Problem_Foods">Staying Away from Problem Foods</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_3916879421" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3916879421')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid canned or bottled beverages.</b> Sports drinks, sodas, and flavored teas or lemonades are usually packed to the brim with HFCS. Be wary when choosing diet or “zero” drinks as well, since they often contain artificial sweeteners. If you must get your soda fix, buy drinks from bottlers who’ve chosen to use only natural cane sugar.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Check the <a href="/Celebrate-Passover" title="Celebrate Passover">Passover</a> section of your supermarket. Some soda companies produce a sugar/sucrose-based version of their products around Passover for Jews who are restricted by custom from eating corn during this time.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_733c2fe9d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_733c2fe9d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid fast food.</b> HFCS is hidden throughout many different types of fast food to increase flavor. Aside from the obvious areas, like sweets, you’ll also find HFCS in burgers, chicken patties, and other surprising foods. Eat foods made from natural ingredients at home to control what goes into the final product.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_5e5f986661" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5e5f986661')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid boxed or prepackaged meals.</b> It’s good that you are trying to eat at home, but don’t make the mistake of taking the easy route with boxed meals. If HFCS is not in the main part of the meal, such as the pasta in boxed macaroni and cheese, then it is likely in the sauce packet. If you are looking for a meal shortcut without HFCS, buy precooked main dishes, like roasted chicken, from your local deli.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=289092" href="#/Image:Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_645deb4389" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_645deb4389')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg/aid289092-v4-728px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose 100% juice over juice cocktails.</b> With pure juice drinks you’ll get natural sugars, whereas cocktails are often packed with HFCS and other artificial ingredients. It’s still a good idea to limit the amount of juice that you drink overall. As an alternative, pick up a piece of whole fruit and get the fiber benefits.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="final_li">
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use caution when buying breakfast cereals and granola bars.</b> Some granola bars actually have more sugar than their chocolate counterparts. Try replacing a sugar-filled cereal with steel-cut oatmeal instead.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="289092" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="337241" data-caid="338114" data-cqid="337258" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="959717" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105122" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is there like an experiment that we conduct on the food to check the existence of HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/5/50/Claudia-Carberry.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Claudia-Carberry.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd" target="_blank">Claudia Carberry, RD</a><br/>
	Registered Dietitian
</div>
Claudia Carberry is an Outpatient Dietitian at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences. She received her MS in Nutrition from the University of Tennessee Knoxville in 2010.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/5/50/Claudia-Carberry.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Claudia-Carberry.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=claudiacarberry%2Crd#claudiacarberry%2Crd" target="_blank">Claudia Carberry, RD</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Registered Dietitian</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No, you can't test for it at home. Looking at the ingredient list is the best way to tell if your food contains HFCS.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>5</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="246585" data-caid="247458" data-cqid="246602" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1473547" data-submitter_id="1702148" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Are there any powdered creamers that do not contain HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/1/1c/1702148.jpg?20170329202754)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:AbigailAbernathy">AbigailAbernathy</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Powdered creamers are bad not because they have HFCS, they're bad because they contain hydrogenated oils, which are trans fats. Trans fats are the fats you want to avoid.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>8</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="55659" data-caid="56532" data-cqid="55676" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="392947" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="17">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it possible for me to avoid high-fructose corn syrup without having to read the ingredients on every package of food I buy?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Not if you truly need to or want to avoid it. It is a pain to read all of the labels in the beginning, but you quickly will learn what brands and products to avoid.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>17</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="258253" data-caid="259126" data-cqid="258270" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1658838" data-submitter_id="1702148" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">If the label says brown sugar, is this HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/1/1c/1702148.jpg?20170329202754)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:AbigailAbernathy">AbigailAbernathy</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No. Not all sugar is high fructose corn syrup. HFCS is usually it's own ingredient. Look for anything that has the word "syrup" in it. Avoid those.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>6</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="216132" data-caid="217005" data-cqid="216149" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1047195" data-submitter_id="1702148" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="10">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Which yogurts are low in HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/1/1c/1702148.jpg?20170329202754)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:AbigailAbernathy">AbigailAbernathy</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Dannon's Oikos Triple Zero brand yogurt is a great source of protein and fiber without any HFCS.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>10</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="280013" data-caid="280886" data-cqid="280030" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1262948" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it true that a food is HFCS-free if it says, "No High Fructose Corn Syrup" on the package?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Not necessarily. It is still a good idea to read over the ingredients list closely, as sometimes they will include HFCS under a different name, like fructose or corn fructose. You can also always call the manufacturer directly to ask about the ingredients of their products. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>3</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="280018" data-caid="280891" data-cqid="280035" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1281714" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What is the difference between corn syrup and HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">They are both types of sugars. However, corn syrup is closer to pure glucose (sugar), whereas HFCS has been modified many times. HFCS is believed to be more harmful for your health, but both types should be avoided as they can contribute to a variety of health problems, including diabetes. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="296530" data-caid="297403" data-cqid="296547" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1242096" data-submitter_id="1702148" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Do homemade jams and jellies, where I actually pick the fruit and make the jams and jellies using cane sugar, contain any HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/1/1c/1702148.jpg?20170329202754)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:AbigailAbernathy">AbigailAbernathy</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">HFCS is not naturally occurring, it can only exist if someone puts it in. Cane sugar is not considered HFCS. Fruit also naturally has fructose, a kind of sugar. But please be careful. Fructose may be naturally occurring, but in large quantities it can damage your liver.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="281690" data-caid="282563" data-cqid="281707" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1674384" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">So the Sara Lee and Nature's Own wheat breads are the only one that are free of HFCS?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Nature's Pride and Pepperidge Farm also offer HFCS-free breads. You can also talk with the bakery section of your local store to see if they make any fresh breads without HFCS. Sometimes it can actually be cheaper to buy freshly-baked bread when you are looking for ones made with quality ingredients. </div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>To move away from sodas, add a bit of flavor to your water by putting a fruit slice into it.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Even if you get sugar from sources other than HFCS, it is best to keep your overall sugar intake low. The World Health Organization recommends that sugar should make up no more than 10% of your daily calorie intake. Ideally, you should have no more than 25 grams (about 6 teaspoons) of sugar per day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>It is particularly important to eliminate HFCS during pregnancy. According to one study, exposure to HFCS in the womb may have negative side effects, such as insulin resistance, for a fetus.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To avoid high fructose corn syrup, try to eat fresh, whole foods instead of canned or frozen foods, which often contain high fructose corn syrup. Also, stick with plain foods whenever possible over sweetened versions with toppings and sauces since high fructose corn syrup is found in a lot of toppings and additives. You should also avoid canned or bottled beverages, like soda, sports drinks, and flavored teas, as well as fast food and processed foods. <span id="summary_last_sentence">To learn how to use healthy substitutions for high fructose corn syrup, scroll down!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup",
    "name": "Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a8\/Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg\/aid289092-v4-1200px-Avoid-High-Fructose-Corn-Syrup-Step-14.jpg",

    "author": {

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Claudia Carberry, RD"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Making Healthy Food Choices",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Read food labels. Before you buy anything at the grocery store, quickly look over the label and see if HFCS is listed in the ingredients. If you see HFCS, pick out an alternative brand of the same food without it. This may take you a while on your first few shopping trips, but soon you\u2019ll figure out which brands to buy and which ones to avoid.[2]\nSome brands may advertise \u201cno high fructose corn syrup\u201d on the package, only to have it listed in the ingredients under a different name. HFCS is also called: corn sugar, maize syrup, glucose syrup, fructose syrup, isolated fructose, and crystalline fructose.[3]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Be selective when buying \u201cnatural\u201d or \u201corganic.\u201d The word \u201cnatural\u201d can be placed on a wide variety of foods containing HFCS, as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn\u2019t regulate the label. Even a food labeled \u201c100% organic\u201d may contain organic HFCS, so it is important to always examine the ingredient and nutrition facts labels. You\u2019ll usually spend a bit more to get HFCS-free organic foods, but the peace of mind is well worth it.[4]\nTo find organic produce in your local grocery store you may need to go toward aisles set aside in a health food area.\nMany breads tout their \u201cwhole grain\u201d status as a way to hide their inclusion of HFCS and harmful chemicals. Whole grain items are usually the best choice, but they are not all equal in quality.[5]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do a pantry purge. Go into your kitchen, open up your pantry, and look at the nutrition label for each food item that you own. Have a trashcan nearby and toss any foods with HFCS into it. Keep going until your pantry is \u201cclean.\u201d Then, head out to the store to buy non-HFCS foods to replace your stock.\n\nIf you aren\u2019t comfortable throwing away the food outright, you can always donate it to a food bank. However, that could also be considered just passing the nutrition problem along. It\u2019s your call."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Go for fresh foods, instead of canned or frozen. Canned fruit is convenient, but it is stripped of its fiber during processing. A piece of whole fruit can give you a fiber boost along with the sweetness of natural sugar. Exchange canned items, such as premade pasta sauce, for healthier options, like making your own sauce out of fresh tomatoes.[6]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Go with plain foods. Choose basic vanilla yogurt, steel-cut oatmeal, and other foods without sauces or toppings. HFCS often hides in fruit toppings in otherwise healthy food options, like yogurt. By adding your own fresh fruit, such as strawberry slices, you can control the portion sizes as well.[7]\nFor example, some sweetened yogurts contain over 40 grams (1.4 ounces) of sugar, including HFCS.[8]\nDon\u2019t forget spices when adding flavor to plain foods. Cinnamon, ginger, and even pepper are all good options."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Buy higher quality sweets. If you have a bit of a sweet tooth, that is okay. Just buy candies and treats made under the highest production standards, even if they are imported. They may be more expensive, but counteract this by allowing yourself only one small piece as an occasional treat.[9]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Making Substitutions",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use fruit as a sweetener. Choose your favorite fruits, such as bananas, and incorporate them into foods that normally would contain extra sugars or HFCS. Mix banana slices into your steel-cut oatmeal or into plain, vanilla yogurt. Dates or bananas can also substitute for sugar in many baked recipes.[10]\nRegular table sugar is another option. However, still try to use any sweeteners, even natural ones, in moderation."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose honey as a sweetener. Buy some raw honey at your local farmer\u2019s market or specialty grocery. Add it into foods 1 teaspoon (5 ml) at a time to sweeten them up. Not only will you get the flavor, you\u2019ll get antioxidants and essential nutrients, like vitamin B6.[11]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Pack healthy snacks. To keep yourself from reaching for that HFCS-filled candy bar, pack some fruit slices in your bag for the day. Or, get a small container of hummus and some pre-cut carrot sticks. Not only will you avoid the negative effects of HFCS, you\u2019ll get a boost of vitamins and nutrients.[12]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Make your own salad dressing or other condiments. Many salad dressings advertise themselves as \u201clow-calorie\u201d or \u201clow fat\u201d and then compensate for the missing flavor by adding in HFCS. Create your own dressing by mixing together some olive oil, pepper, lemon juice, and balsamic vinegar. Experiment with recipes for other condiments too, like ketchup, barbeque sauce, mayo, or mustard.[13]\nWatch your portion sizes with condiments as well. A single tablespoon of barbecue sauce can cost you upwards of 5 grams (0.18 oz) of sugar or HFCS."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Staying Away from Problem Foods",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid canned or bottled beverages. Sports drinks, sodas, and flavored teas or lemonades are usually packed to the brim with HFCS. Be wary when choosing diet or \u201czero\u201d drinks as well, since they often contain artificial sweeteners. If you must get your soda fix, buy drinks from bottlers who\u2019ve chosen to use only natural cane sugar.[14]\nCheck the Passover section of your supermarket. Some soda companies produce a sugar\/sucrose-based version of their products around Passover for Jews who are restricted by custom from eating corn during this time."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid fast food. HFCS is hidden throughout many different types of fast food to increase flavor. Aside from the obvious areas, like sweets, you\u2019ll also find HFCS in burgers, chicken patties, and other surprising foods. Eat foods made from natural ingredients at home to control what goes into the final product.[15]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid boxed or prepackaged meals. It\u2019s good that you are trying to eat at home, but don\u2019t make the mistake of taking the easy route with boxed meals. If HFCS is not in the main part of the meal, such as the pasta in boxed macaroni and cheese, then it is likely in the sauce packet. If you are looking for a meal shortcut without HFCS, buy precooked main dishes, like roasted chicken, from your local deli.[16]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose 100% juice over juice cocktails. With pure juice drinks you\u2019ll get natural sugars, whereas cocktails are often packed with HFCS and other artificial ingredients. It\u2019s still a good idea to limit the amount of juice that you drink overall. As an alternative, pick up a piece of whole fruit and get the fiber benefits.[17]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use caution when buying breakfast cereals and granola bars. Some granola bars actually have more sugar than their chocolate counterparts. Try replacing a sugar-filled cereal with steel-cut oatmeal instead.[18]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup.  High fructose corn syrup (HFCS) is used as a sweetener for many processed foods. To eliminate HFCS from your diet, start by closely reading nutrition labels before buying foods. Avoid canned, frozen,..."

title: How to Avoid High Fructose Corn Syrup
content_html:
Read food labels. Before you buy anything at the grocery store, quickly look over the label and see if HFCS is listed in the ingredients. If you see HFCS, pick out an alternative brand of the same food without it. This may take you a while on your first few shopping trips, but soon you’ll figure out which brands to buy and which ones to avoid.[2]
  • Some brands may advertise “no high fructose corn syrup” on the package, only to have it listed in the ingredients under a different name. HFCS is also called: corn sugar, maize syrup, glucose syrup, fructose syrup, isolated fructose, and crystalline fructose.[3]
Be selective when buying “natural” or “organic.” The word “natural” can be placed on a wide variety of foods containing HFCS, as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn’t regulate the label. Even a food labeled “100% organic” may contain organic HFCS, so it is important to always examine the ingredient and nutrition facts labels. You’ll usually spend a bit more to get HFCS-free organic foods, but the peace of mind is well worth it.[4]
  • To find organic produce in your local grocery store you may need to go toward aisles set aside in a health food area.
  • Many breads tout their “whole grain” status as a way to hide their inclusion of HFCS and harmful chemicals. Whole grain items are usually the best choice, but they are not all equal in quality.[5]
Do a pantry purge. Go into your kitchen, open up your pantry, and look at the nutrition label for each food item that you own. Have a trashcan nearby and toss any foods with HFCS into it. Keep going until your pantry is “clean.” Then, head out to the store to buy non-HFCS foods to replace your stock.
  • If you aren’t comfortable throwing away the food outright, you can always donate it to a food bank. However, that could also be considered just passing the nutrition problem along. It’s your call.
Go for fresh foods, instead of canned or frozen. Canned fruit is convenient, but it is stripped of its fiber during processing. A piece of whole fruit can give you a fiber boost along with the sweetness of natural sugar. Exchange canned items, such as premade pasta sauce, for healthier options, like making your own sauce out of fresh tomatoes.[6]
Go with plain foods. Choose basic vanilla yogurt, steel-cut oatmeal, and other foods without sauces or toppings. HFCS often hides in fruit toppings in otherwise healthy food options, like yogurt. By adding your own fresh fruit, such as strawberry slices, you can control the portion sizes as well.[7]
  • For example, some sweetened yogurts contain over 40 grams (1.4 ounces) of sugar, including HFCS.[8]
  • Don’t forget spices when adding flavor to plain foods. Cinnamon, ginger, and even pepper are all good options.
Buy higher quality sweets. If you have a bit of a sweet tooth, that is okay. Just buy candies and treats made under the highest production standards, even if they are imported. They may be more expensive, but counteract this by allowing yourself only one small piece as an occasional treat.[9]
Use fruit as a sweetener. Choose your favorite fruits, such as bananas, and incorporate them into foods that normally would contain extra sugars or HFCS. Mix banana slices into your steel-cut oatmeal or into plain, vanilla yogurt. Dates or bananas can also substitute for sugar in many baked recipes.[10]
  • Regular table sugar is another option. However, still try to use any sweeteners, even natural ones, in moderation.
Choose honey as a sweetener. Buy some raw honey at your local farmer’s market or specialty grocery. Add it into foods 1 teaspoon (5 ml) at a time to sweeten them up. Not only will you get the flavor, you’ll get antioxidants and essential nutrients, like vitamin B6.[11]
Pack healthy snacks. To keep yourself from reaching for that HFCS-filled candy bar, pack some fruit slices in your bag for the day. Or, get a small container of hummus and some pre-cut carrot sticks. Not only will you avoid the negative effects of HFCS, you’ll get a boost of vitamins and nutrients.[12]
Make your own salad dressing or other condiments. Many salad dressings advertise themselves as “low-calorie” or “low fat” and then compensate for the missing flavor by adding in HFCS. Create your own dressing by mixing together some olive oil, pepper, lemon juice, and balsamic vinegar. Experiment with recipes for other condiments too, like ketchup, barbeque sauce, mayo, or mustard.[13]
  • Watch your portion sizes with condiments as well. A single tablespoon of barbecue sauce can cost you upwards of 5 grams (0.18 oz) of sugar or HFCS.
Avoid canned or bottled beverages. Sports drinks, sodas, and flavored teas or lemonades are usually packed to the brim with HFCS. Be wary when choosing diet or “zero” drinks as well, since they often contain artificial sweeteners. If you must get your soda fix, buy drinks from bottlers who’ve chosen to use only natural cane sugar.[14]
  • Check the Passover section of your supermarket. Some soda companies produce a sugar/sucrose-based version of their products around Passover for Jews who are restricted by custom from eating corn during this time.
Avoid fast food. HFCS is hidden throughout many different types of fast food to increase flavor. Aside from the obvious areas, like sweets, you’ll also find HFCS in burgers, chicken patties, and other surprising foods. Eat foods made from natural ingredients at home to control what goes into the final product.[15]
Avoid boxed or prepackaged meals. It’s good that you are trying to eat at home, but don’t make the mistake of taking the easy route with boxed meals. If HFCS is not in the main part of the meal, such as the pasta in boxed macaroni and cheese, then it is likely in the sauce packet. If you are looking for a meal shortcut without HFCS, buy precooked main dishes, like roasted chicken, from your local deli.[16]
Choose 100% juice over juice cocktails. With pure juice drinks you’ll get natural sugars, whereas cocktails are often packed with HFCS and other artificial ingredients. It’s still a good idea to limit the amount of juice that you drink overall. As an alternative, pick up a piece of whole fruit and get the fiber benefits.[17]
Use caution when buying breakfast cereals and granola bars. Some granola bars actually have more sugar than their chocolate counterparts. Try replacing a sugar-filled cereal with steel-cut oatmeal instead.[18]
